awd_titl_txt: CRII: CHS: Do virtual behaviors represent reality: Examining human behavioral validity in virtual reality interactions
awd_abstract_narration:
Virtual reality is becoming commonplace to study human behavior because it affords simulations of various situations, thus is advantageous for standardized training, education, and experimental research. However, virtual reality may not contain all sensory cues (e.g., smell, scent) and non-perceptual factors (e.g., consequence, time pressure) that would evoke behaviors normally exhibited in the real world. There is limited research on behavioral validity of participants in virtual reality experiments. Thus, the principal goal of this research is to study the validity of human behavior in virtual reality, and thereby strengthen the transferability and generalizability of findings. Researchers will benefit from this work, as they will be able to apply the postulated perceptual-behavioral framework. Society in general will benefit, as private industry will be able to leverage the outcomes and guidelines to yield enhanced virtual reality technologies and other consumer products.   

There are two primary research objectives.  (1) Understand effects of immersion on perceptual-behavioral relationship in an immersive virtual environment. Immersion is a quantifiable measure of virtual reality. A more immersive virtual environment will offer, for example, more extensive cues than a less immersive virtual environment. (2) Study and characterize non-perceptual factors that influence behavioral validity in an immersive virtual environment. Non-perceptual factors include time pressure and consequences (but not life or death because it is virtual). Behaviors (performance and actions) exhibited by participants will be examined in both research objectives. Empirical experiments will be conducted to collect quantitative and qualitative data to support the investigation driven by these two research objectives.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
As virtual reality becomes commonplace technology for research, education and training, and even healthcare, this research aims to examine the human behavioral validity in virtual reality. Behavioral validity refers to the degree to which a person's behavior in a simulation (or virtual reality ) approximates his/her behavior in the real world. For research that wishes to leverage virtual reality to study human behaviors, reactions, or performances, it becomes important to obtain results that resemble those in the real world. 

The outcomes of this project have intellectually contributed to the understanding of human behaviors and human factors in virtual reality. In particular, we conducted an experiment to study the factors that influence a person's behavior and perceived experiences, which included sense of presence, response time, workload, and anxiety. In the experiment, we compared peoples' behaviors and perceived experiences across three experimental conditions: real world, virtual reality made using realistic scans of the real world (VR-LiDAR), and virtual reality made using computer aided design models (VR-CAD). The data generated from this experiment enabled researchers to study human behavioral validity and to build statistical models for discriminating behavioral patterns. Moreover, we generated both quantitative and qualitative data that were complementary and supported the understanding of human behaviors. The results revealed that the visual appearance of the experimental environment affected the sense of presence and response time. Moreover, through a mixed-methods approach, we collected and analyzed qualitative interview data, which revealed that the "meta-knowledge" possessed by people affected their behaviors in virtual reality (i.e., information or prior knowledge possessed by individuals prior to the experiment affected their behavior in virtual reality).

The outcomes of this project have broader impacts on the research community and the society. First, subsequent virtual reality experiments conducted in our lab have utilized the findings and recommendations from this experiment. Moreover, we have presented the findings at the Applied Ergonomics Conference and are preparing a journal manuscript to be submitted to Human Factors. Next, the virtual reality scenarios (VR-LiDAR and VR-CAD) produced for the experiment were used for lab tours, open houses, and demonstrations for classes. 

In sum, the outcomes of this project advanced the understanding of human behaviors in virtual reality, design recommendations for experiment scenarios in virtual reality, implementation of mixed-methods for understanding human behaviors in virtual reality. The products of this project were disseminated to relevant research communities, and also helped expose K-12 students to virtual reality through a series of outreach activities.


Last Modified: 07/07/2022
Modified by: Karen B Chen
